questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding accommodative esotropia?

options.label: A
options.text: It is the most common type of squint

options.label: B
options.text: Miotics are used as the treatment strategy in the high AC/A ratio

options.label: C
options.text: It is associated with high myopia.

options.label: D
options.text: Refractive type can be fully corrected by the use of spectacles

questions.correct_answer: C. It is associated with high myopia.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

It is associated with high myopia. Accommodative esotropia is one of the most common types of strabismus in childhood. The incidence is estimated at 2% of the population. It is usually found in patients with moderate amounts of hyperopia. As the patient accommodates or focuses the eyes, the eyes converge. The over-convergence associated with the accommodation to overcome a hyperopic refractive error can cause a loss of binocular control and lead to the development of esotropia Spectacle correction is the initial treatment for accommodative esotropia . Generally, the full cycloplegic correction should be given initially.

Highyeild:

Convergent strabismus (esodeviation): AETIOLOGY : These are generally more common in childhood and hypermetropes . Racial differences in prevalence are possible. Defective vision in one eye , such as high ametropia, opacities in the media or ocular disease, Disturbances in muscular equilibrium , usually due to a congenital mal-insertion or defective development of one or more of the extrinsic muscles. CLASSIFICATION OF ESODEVIATION: Type Criterion Nonaccommodative Esotropia at distance = near fixation; no change with refractive correction Accommodative • Refractive (normal AC/A ratio) • Non Refractive (high AC/A ratio) • Mixed Esotropia at distance ≥ near fixation; fully corrected by hyperopic correction for distance Esotropia at near fixation > distance or manifesting only at near; fully corrected by an additional hyperopic correction for near work Partially accommodative Esotropia is partly corrected by the use of refractive correction Treatment The routine management of a case of comitant convergent strabismus in a child should be undertaken at the earliest possible age. Full spectacle correction should be ordered for constant use. Miotic drugs with anticholinesterase activity such as di-isopropyl fluorophosphate (DFP) or echothiophate: 2. If the child refuses to wear glasses or is unable to use spectacles such as a child who is younger than 2 years, has a flat nasal bridge, is a hypermetrope and has a convergent squint, it is sometimes easier to eliminate accommodation by temporarily treating him with miotic drugs with anticholinesterase activity Orthoptic training Surgical treatment

questions.text: A person having limitation of adduction in the left eye. In the right eye saccadic movement on abduction and normal convergence. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Internuclear Ophthalmoplegia Internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO) is a disorder of conjugate lateral gaze in which the affected eye shows impairment of adduction. When an attempt is made to gaze contra laterally (relative to the affected eye), the affected eye adducts minimally, if at all. The contralateral eye abducts, however, with nystagmus. Additionally, the divergence of the eyes leads to horizontal diplopia. That is, if the right eye is affected the patient will "see double" when looking to the left, seeing two images side-by-side. Convergence is generally preserved

Highyeild:

Internuclear ophthalmoplegia is an ocular movement disorder caused by a lesion of the medial longitudinal fasciculus. It is characterized by impaired adduction of the ipsilateral eye with nystagmus of the abducting eye. Medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF), is a fibre tract responsible for transmitting information that is vital for the coordination of different eye movements. It is a paired white matter tract passing close to the midline, through the brainstem lying ventral to the cerebral aqueduct in the midbrain and the fourth ventricle in the pons and medulla. It is the final common pathway for different types of conjugate eye movements like saccades, smooth pursuit, and vestibulocochlear reflex , and forms a communication between all the ocular motor nuclei Ophthalmoplegia can also occur due to certain toxins . The chief exogenous poisons causing ophthalmoplegia are lead and ptomaines ; the chief toxins, are diphtheria and influenza.

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Congenital absence of MR - not the correct option Option: C. Partial third nerve palsy - Option: D. Duane's retraction syndrome

questions.text: Superior oblique testing for the 4th nerve is done by checking its intorsion while asking the subject to look-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Down and in The Superior oblique muscle can be tested by requesting the patient to adduct the eye and then asking to depress the eye . Failure to depress the eye during adduction indicates a problem with the superior oblique muscle or the trochlear nerve.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - The superior oblique muscle's primary action is eye intorsion, with secondary and tertiary actions being eye depression and abduction, respectively. Option: A. - Because the superior oblique helps depress the eye, trochlear nerve palsy results in upward deviation of the eye (hypertropia). Option: B. - Patients with trochlear nerve palsy will thus complain of vertical diplopia (double vision), often with a torsional component, that is greatest on downgaze and to the side opposite the paralyzed superior oblique muscle. Option: D. - These patients may sometimes have obvious limitations of eye movement down when the eye is adducted, but the problem is often quite subtle.

questions.text: The yoke muscle of the right superior oblique is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Left inferior rectus The muscles that move the eye are called the extraocular muscles. There are six of them on each eye. They work together in pairs— complementary (or yoke) muscles pulling the eyes in the same direction(s) , and opposites (or antagonists) pulling the eyes in opposite directions.

questions.correct_answer: C. The image is magnified 15 times
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The image is magnified 15 times The procedure shown in the image is direct ophthalmoscopy and in this image gets magnified 15 times

Highyeild:

Ophthalmoscopy, also called funduscopy, is a test that allows a health professional to see inside the fundus of the eye and other structures using an ophthalmoscope (or funduscopy). It is done as part of an eye examination and may be done as part of a routine physical examination. It is crucial in determining the health of the retina, optic disc, and vitreous humour It is of two major types: Direct ophthalmoscopy is one that produces an upright, or unreversed, image of approximately 15 times magnification. Indirect ophthalmoscopy is one that produces an inverted, or reversed, image of 2 to 5 times magnification Features Direct Indirect Image Nature Position Brightness Stereopsis Resolution Field Peripheral view Working distance Scleral indentation Virtual, erect, magnified 15x Towards the retina of the patient Less bright Nil Poor Small 10° Not possible Very short Not possible Real, inverted magnified 3-4× Between the condensing lens and observer Very bright Good Better Large 37° Well seen Long Possible

questions.text: Image C indicates which of the following interpretations:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Right eye suppression In the normal binocular single vision, the patient sees all four lights in the absence of manifest squint I n right suppression, the patient sees only three green lights . In diplopia, the patient sees five lights (2 red and 3 green)

Highyeild:

In Worth's four dot test patient wears red-green glasses with red in front of R/E and green over L/E and views a box with four lights- one red, two green, and one white. Red can be seen through only R/E & green through L/E & white light can be seen with both eyes. The results are interpreted depending on the patient’s observation as If the patient sees all four lights in the absence of squint = Normal binocular vision If the patient sees all four lights in the presence of manifest squint = ARC Only two red lights seen = left suppression Only three green lights seen = right suppression Three green lights and two red lights seen alternatively = alternating suppression Five lights seen ( 2 red & 3 green) = diplopia

questions.text: 66 years old diabetic patient came to OPD. On examination, it was found that primary deviation is lesser than secondary deviation. The forced duction test was found to be negative. Which of the following types of squint is most likely to be present in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Paralytic squint In the given scenario, the secondary deviation is more than the primary deviation which is suggestive of incomitant squint. To differentiate between paralytic and restrictive squint, a forced duction test is performed, which in the patient is negative.

Highyeild:

Clinical Features Paralytic Squint Restrictive Squint Deviation in primary position Present and is proportional to the degree of underaction of the affected muscle May be present, absent or paradoxical; is generally disproportionately mild compared to the degree of underaction and can even be paradoxical, e.g. an exotropia in Duane retraction syndrome with a deficiency of abduction Forced duction test or ability to move the eye mechanically using a forceps to hold the anaesthetized eye at the limbus Negative, i.e. the eye can be easily moved in the direction of restricted movement Positive, i.e. the eye cannot be mechanically moved in the direction of restricted movement Active force generation test Negative or weak force generation The positive or normal force generated by the muscle

questions.text: The pattern of esotropia shown in a given image is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

V pattern esotropia The terms 'A' or 'V' pattern squint are labelled when the amount of deviation in the squinting eye varies by more than 10° and 15°, respectively, between upward and downward gaze. a ‘V’ pattern is seen in a convergent squint which increases on a downward gaze

Highyeild:

‘A’ and ‘V’ phenomena A tendency for the eyes to diverge on elevation is physiological. Any squint can show a variation in deviation in upward and downward gaze and, depending on the nature of the squint, an ‘ A’ or ‘V’ pattern can be For example, a ‘V’ pattern is seen in a convergent squint which increases on a downward gaze but in a divergent squint, a ‘V’ pattern is seen when the deviation is maximum in an upward gaze and less in a downward gaze. The ‘A’ and ‘V’ phenomena should be assessed by the cover test in 25°upward and downward gaze. Etiology : Oblique muscle dysfunction is the commonest cause of AV pattern. Other causes include horizontal rectus muscle dysfunction, vertical muscle dysfunction and certain orbital factors. In general, it is found that the oblique muscles are of more importance in the production of the ‘A’ and ‘V ’ phenomena than the vertical recti. Usually, overaction of the inferior oblique or weakness of the superior oblique leads to a ‘V’ pattern and overaction of the superior oblique weakness of the inferior oblique to an ‘A’ pattern. Weakening and strengthening of the oblique muscles, therefore, are well-recognized methods of influencing the ‘A’ and ‘V’ phenomena.

The reverse occurs in 'V' esotropia. The reverse occurs in 'V' exotropia. Option: B . In 'A' exotropia the amount of deviation decreases in the upward gaze and increases in the downward gaze . Clinical presentations Option: D. In a divergent squint a ‘V’ pattern is seen when the deviation is maximum in the upward gaze and less in the downward gaze.

questions.text: Recession & Resection surgeries are based on which mechanism of EOM movements?

options.label: B
options.text: Length & arc of contact of muscle

questions.correct_answer: B. Length & arc of contact of muscle
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Length & arc of contact of muscle The power of a muscle is proportional to its length & arc of contact . Retroplacement of the insertion of muscle ( recession) weakens the action of muscle by shortening its effective length & by reducing its arc of contact in various positions of gaze. Advancements in the EOM have a strengthening effect because of the increase in the effective length & arc of contact of the muscle.
